sec.p:
Of the 69 species considered, 5 were classed as SPEC2 and 12 were classed as SPEC3 ( Table S1). T mean for species classified according to SPEC status across experts was higher for those listed as of conservation concern (i.e., combining SPEC2 and SPEC3 species; mean ±se = 0.45 ± 0.03, n = 19) than unlisted species (mean ±se = 0.27 ± 0.03, n = 19). The difference was highly significant (Wilcoxon test, W = 173, p = 0.001). There was no significant correlation between the number of relevant citations and T mean ( r
s = 0.21, n = 69, p = 0.08).

The mapping exercise highlighted a moderate amount of spatial variation in the threat scores at the community-level ( Fig. 5). Both longitudinal and latitudinal gradients of threat were statistically significant (rho lat = − 0.50 P < 0.001, rho lon = − 0.49 p < 0.001). Average threat scores tended to decrease when moving eastwards and southwards.
